p: Although CHIKV is an alphavirus, it shares epidemiological, ecological and biogeographic characteristics with flavivirus YFV, DENV and ZIKV associated with transmission by A. aegypti, including the dependence of jungle Aedes in the forest cycle and domestic Aedes in the cycle of transmission of human epidemics ( Gould and Higgs, 2009, Chen et al., 2016). It is likely that during the 17th and 19th centuries, dengue and chikungunya fever were misdiagnosed; as a result, some of the epidemics that were clinically diagnosed as dengue in the Americas and in Africa during the 17th–19th centuries were probably caused by CHIKV. Chikungunya fever, native to East Africa and Zanzibar, had crossed the Indian Ocean at intervals of approximately 40–50 years from 1770 to 2005–14 ( Gould et al., 2017).
